Award.AwardTitle: NUE: Engineering Innovation in Biomedical Nanotechnology

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this NUE project, Engineering Innovation in Biomedical Nanotechnology, at the University of Arizona (UA), under the direction of Dr. Eniko T. Enikov, is to develop to introduce nanoscale science and engineering through an innovative use of a technical elective senior design course in mechatronics, followed by an ABET-mandated senior-level engineeirng capstone design project.

The proposed activities include: 1) Delivery of mechatronics design course focused on use of giant magneto-resistance (GMR) sensors and the fabrication of an electro-spinning manufacturing cell. 2) Mentoring of two senior capstone design teams/year comprised of engineering and business students who will use the GMR sensors and electro-spinning apparatus in clinical applications (In collaboration with the UA College of Medicine and the College of Management). 3) Demonstration of a working prototype of a smart catheter with embedded flow sensor enabled by the application of super-paramagnetic nano-particles.

The proposed project seeks to develop a model for nanotechnology education that can be adopted by other institutions. To broaden the impact of the project, the PIs have partnered with the UA McGuire Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation at the Eller College of Management whereby student teams of engineering and business students will develop product ideas based on nanotechnology and subsequently create product prototypes as part of the senior capstone design course in engineering.

The project builds on the prior work of the PI, Dr. Enikov, in developing undergraduate laboratory experiments in nanotechnology, which showed that an evolutionary design approach can be used successfully to complete a relatively complicated nanotechnology project within the framework of the standard junior- and senior-year courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many modern (bio) sensors and drug delivery devices utilize some form of nanotechnology. Using

magnetic nanoparticles, it is now possible to detect bio-molecular processes. Similarly, new manufacturing processes based on the production of sub-micron fibers are used in in the production of scaffolds for artificial tissues and organs. However, efforts to introduce nanotechnology to engineering students accustomed to touch and feel the objects of their study pose a challenge. Most such curricula leads to demonstration-style courses and imaging studies, without direct connection to an application. The objective of this project is to introduce nanoscale science and technology through innovative use of several junior- and senior-level courses, leading to the construction of a prototype of nanotechnology-enabled product.  The project builds on the prior work of the PI in developing undergraduate laboratory experiments in nanotechnology, which showed that an evolutionary design approach can be used successfully to complete a relatively complicated nanotechnology project within the framework of the standard junior- and senior-year courses. 

Intellectual Merit:

During the course of this grant, over one-hundred participants received training in the fabrication methods of nano-sensors, manufacturing of nano-fibers, and development of electronic interfaces for measuring nano-scale phenomena. The participants explored several different applications of nanotechnology including

-       Demonstration of a novel ventricular-peritoneal shunt utilizing MTJ sensors

-       Development of electrospinning apparatus for production of biopolymeric nano-fibers

-       Development of anno-rectal tonometer for screening of spinal trauma and the onset of a Cauda Equina Syndrome (CES).

Broader Impact:                     

The project resulted in a curricular innovation at the PI’s institution providing hands-on training in the design of biomedical devices through the entire four-year undergraduate program. Additionally, the effort resulted in several invention disclosures that could improve the diagnosis of spinal cord injuries and contribute to the economic development of the country.

Modified by: Eniko T Enikov
